review.title: An Analysis of Tournament Structure
review.abstract: This paper explores a novel way for analyzing the tournament structures to find a best suitable one for the tournament under consideration. It concerns about three aspects such as tournament conducting cost, competitiveness development and ranking precision. It then proposes a new method using progress tree to detect potential throwaway matches. The analysis performed using the proposed method reveals the strengths and weaknesses of tournament structures. As a conclusion, single elimination is best if we want to qualify one winner only, all matches conducted are exciting in term of competitiveness. Double elimination with proper seeding system is a better choice if we want to qualify more winners. A reasonable number of extra matches need to be conducted in exchange of being able to qualify top four winners. Round-robin gives reliable ranking precision for all participants. However, its conduction cost is very high, and it fails to maintain competitiveness development.

metadata.title: An Analysis of Tournament Structure

sections.text: This paper examines a novel method of analysing tournament structures in order to find the most suitable one for the tournament under consideration, covering three aspects, such as the cost of running the tournament, the development of competitiveness and the precision of ranking. Subsequently, a new method is proposed, using the progress tree to identify potential disposable games. Analysis carried out with the proposed method reveals the strengths and weaknesses of tournament structures. In conclusion, a one-off elimination is best if we want to qualify only one winner, all games carried out are exciting in terms of competitiveness. Double elimination with the right seeding system is a better choice if we want to qualify more winners. In exchange, an appropriate number of additional games must be carried out in order to qualify for the top four winners. Round-Robin provides all participants with reliable ranking precision. However, its implementation costs are very high and it fails to maintain competitiveness development.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The competitive game attracts not only professional players, but also many spectators who are interested in the game. The tournament is a competitive system. It offers some prizes as an objective for participants to compete with each other. It is often used as a formal method to hold official gaming events, to gather professional players, and to attract a large number of spectators. Such major events usually receive sponsorship from various companies and organizations. Therefore, it is necessary to be carefully prepared and conducted in order to avoid disappointment on each side. There are three main concerns in tournament systems: 1. Implementation costs (CC), that is, the number of games required to perform. Second, the development of competitiveness (CD). That is, to minimize the disposable games in which participants are not so motivated to play their best. In terms of competitive gaming, some research finds that unequal teams tend to attract less interest from spectators.

sections.heading: 2 Analyzing Method
sections.text: This section presents two important aspects for the analysis of the quality of tournament structures: development of competitiveness and precision of ranking.

sections.heading: 2.1 Competitiveness Development
sections.text: The motivation of a participant consists of many factors, but we limit ourselves to the tournament structure in this study. We introduce "progress tree" to demonstrate the perspective of participants in a tournament, to analyze their motivation development during the tournament. The progress tree is constructed on the basis of the graphical model approach [4]. The state of a participant before or after playing a game is considered a node. The state in which the participant no longer plays a game is a leaf node. We show, in Figure 1, an example of a single elimination tournament for 8 participants, and Figure 2 shows his or her progress. While "competitive" means that participants must compete with each other, it is common to have more than one prize rather than goals in a tournament. Therefore, it is necessary to have the prizes comparable in an order.

sections.heading: 2.2 Ranking Precision
sections.text: We see the tournament as a comparison / sorting problem, and each game is a comparison between two players. We assume that there is a game in which a stronger player always wins against a weaker player, and we have all participants with different strengths. There are two ways to check the ranking of such a game: by mathematical evidence or by using all possibilities. In this essay, we simply use the permutation to try out all the possible outcomes, then we can see whether the results are accurate or not. However, the method of the permutation experiment is too difficult if the number of participants is too large, so in this essay we are conducting experiments with only eight participants.

sections.heading: 3 Tournament Structure Analysis
sections.text: We analyze various general tournament systems such as singles, doubles and round robin. To compare them, we illustrate the example of eight participants each.

sections.heading: 3.1 Single Elimination
sections.text: The individual elimination is a kind of elimination tournament in which the loser of each group is eliminated immediately.

sections.heading: 3.1.1 Conduction Cost
sections.text: A pure single elimination system with i rounds has n = 2i participants, and n − 1 games are played. If there were 8 players with KO, there would be 7 games with 3 rounds.

All wins are worth aiming for and the leaderboard results are decided the lowest first.

sections.heading: 3.2 Double Elimination
sections.text: In a standard double elimination tournament, participants are divided into two subordinate brackets (upper and lower brackets). If a participant from the lower bracket loses a game, the participant is eliminated. If a participant from the lower bracket loses, the participant is moved into the lower bracket. The last remaining participant in the lower bracket is the last participant standing as a grand finale in the upper bracket. sections.heading: 3.2.1 Conduction Cost
sections.text: A purely double elimination system with i upper rounds has 2i participants, and (2i − 1) + (2i − 1 − 1) games are played. Thus, in a double elimination tournament for 8 participants, 10 games are played.

sections.heading: 3.2.2 Competitiveness Development
sections.text: Figure 3 shows an elimination tournament for 8 players, and Figure 4 shows its progress. Assuming that comparable prizes are distributed in the correct order in this tournament, we can see from Figure 4 that it has no problems with increasing stability or the possibility of results. Each win has a more favorable value than its loss, and the leaderboard results are decided first.

sections.text: Assuming that we have 8 players with strengths varying from 1 to 8, and the stronger ones always win the match, these players will be divided into 8 starting positions in Figure 3. Even with an increased number of games being played compared to the individual elimination, it still lacks accuracy in ranking. However, the double elimination has two starting nodes (see Figure 4). It can be argued that the double elimination is designed for a multi-tier system, or players are correctly distributed using a scoring system [5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10]. Therefore, stronger participants and weaker participants (seeded) are expected to be properly distributed in the upper and lower brackets.

sections.heading: 3.3 Round-Robin
sections.text: In the round-robin tournament system, all participants must play against each other. In other words, each participant plays once against each other participant. If each participant leads all others twice, this is called a double round-robin.

sections.heading: 3.3.2 Competitiveness Development
sections.text: We show in Figure 5 a progress tree of a round robin tournament with 8 participants. The big difference to elimination tournaments is that from the beginning only the hand of all losses and the hand of all wins is known. Due to this unstable situation, we are not able to calculate stability values of the nodes. As the tournament progresses, the unknown hands will gradually reveal themselves and the stability values of the nodes would be calculated. Furthermore, unstable situations indicate that there are possibilities not to satisfy the progression of stability and the possibility of result conditions.In Table 7, we show an example situation after 5 rounds, and Figure 6 shows its progress tree. In this situation, if participant A wins the next game, his victory would be determined first regardless of his last score. This does not satisfy the progression of stability. In addition, for participants B, F, E, G, R and P even their hands are unknown, so the possibility of 1st place is not within reach.

sections.heading: 3.3.3 Ranking Precision
sections.text: Suppose we have 8 participants with strengths varying from 1 to 8, and stronger participants always win. Then, there is only one result as in Table 8, regardless of how the participants are positioned. Round-robin gives a really accurate ranking in the experiment. However, implementation costs are high and competitiveness development is not good.

sections.heading: 4 Results and Evaluation
sections.text: We show in Table 9 the comparison between single elimination, double elimination and robins. We see that higher management costs are needed to achieve a better ranking accuracy, the result shows that the single elimination system has the lowest costs, while its development of competitiveness is properly maintained. However, its ranking is reliable only for the top 4 winners. Double elimination also has no problem in developing competitiveness. Although it has higher management costs with a proper sowing system, its ranking is accurate for the top 4 winners. Robins, on the other hand, gives a precise ranking to all participants, but can cause excessive costs, which causes the lack of development of competitiveness.

sections.heading: 5 Concluding Remarks
sections.text: In this paper, we proposed a novel method of analyzing tournament structures in order to find the most suitable one for the tournament under consideration. We focused on three aspects, such as the cost of organizing tournaments, developing competitiveness and ranking precision. We proposed a progress tree to identify potential disposable games. The analysis performed with the proposed method reveals the strengths and weaknesses of tournament structures. In conclusion, a one-time elimination is best when we want to qualify only one winner, all games performed are exciting in terms of competitiveness. Double elimination with the right seeding system is a better choice if we want to qualify more winners. An appropriate number of additional matches must be performed in exchange for being able to qualify the top four winners. Round-Robin provides all participants with reliable ranking precision, but its execution costs are very high and it does not succeed in maintaining competitiveness development.
